title: 108_s1610
content: The Act titled "Defined Benefit Pension Plan Reform Act of 2003" includes a section on the emergency investment loss rule for multiemployer plans. The Defined Benefit Pension Plan Reform Act of 2003 introduces an emergency investment loss method for multiemployer plans under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This method allows plans to elect to use the emergency investment loss method instead of amortizing net experience loss, starting from the first plan year with an emergency investment loss occurring after July 1, 1999. The Defined Benefit Pension Plan Reform Act of 2003 introduced the emergency investment loss method for multiemployer plans under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This method allows plans to elect to use it instead of amortizing net experience loss, starting from the first plan year with an emergency investment loss occurring after July 1, 1999. The method calculates the difference between the fair market value of the plan's assets at the end of the plan year and the projected investment return based on the actuarial interest rate. The funding standard account is charged to amortize the plan's emergency investment loss over 30 years in equal annual installments. The emergency investment loss for a year will increase the determined net experience loss for that year, and any excess will be treated as a net experience gain. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allows multiemployer plans to elect the emergency investment loss method instead of amortizing net experience loss. An emergency investment loss is calculated based on the difference between the fair market value of the plan's assets and the value that would have been determined based on the plan's earnings. The funding standard account is charged to amortize the plan's emergency investment loss over 30 years in equal annual installments. If an election is in effect, any net experience gain is increased by the emergency investment loss for that year. The Secretary of the Treasury will prescribe a procedure for multiemployer plans to elect the emergency investment loss method. This method allows for the reduction of net experience loss by the emergency investment loss, with any excess being treated as a net experience gain. The emergency investment loss method allows multiemployer plans to reduce net experience loss by the emergency investment loss, with any excess treated as a net experience gain. Plans have a period of at least 210 days after enactment to file Schedule Bs for the affected plan years. The amendments made by this section apply to years beginning after June 30, 1999. SEC. 3. MORTALITY TABLE ADJUSTMENT. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to establish separate mortality tables for blue-collar and white-collar workers for determining current liability under this subsection starting after December 31, 2003. The Secretary will consider the Society of Actuaries RP-2000 Mortality Table, adjusted for the collar adjustment, to reflect the workforce covered by the plan. Workers will be classified as blue-collar or white-collar based on rules set by the Secretary, including treatment of professional employees. Employees classified as white-collar workers must use prescribed tables for all plans unless prohibited by regulations. This is an amendment to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to establish separate mortality tables for blue-collar and white-collar workers for determining current liability under this subsection. The Secretary of the Treasury considers the Society of Actuaries RP-2000 Mortality Table, adjusted for the collar adjustment, to reflect the workforce covered by the plan. Workers are classified as blue-collar or white-collar based on rules set by the Secretary of the Treasury. The amendments made by this section shall treat professional employees as white-collar workers and require consistent use of tables for all plans established by the employer. The amendments made by this section will be effective as of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4 amends the limitation on deductibility of employer contributions for pension plans by ensuring that the full funding limitation is at least 130 percent of current liability. SEC. 5 requires the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation to notify participants and beneficiaries of plan terminations. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation must provide notice of plan termination proceedings to affected parties within 30 days. The plan administrator must provide a list of participants and beneficiaries to the corporation, who will then notify each affected party in writing. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation must give notice of plan termination proceedings to affected parties through written notice and publication in two major newspapers. This amendment applies to proceedings starting after the enactment of the Act.
